title: Constructing a Recipe Web from Historical Newspapers

author: Marieke van Erp, Faculty of Sciences, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU)

segmentation: Alright, so I'm American up and I work for the Nelons Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, Humanities cluster and this is really the start of a research line, so the research group I'm leading is only a year old and we're really trying to set up new new things and we've been working on extracting recipes from newspapers.
Is there anyone here who works with newspaper data?
OK, not very many.
So the interesting thing about working with humanities researchers is that they really make you look at data differently.
So really, we're using newspapers as.
A view on the past and also customs which might not be the first thing you think about.

Especially not food, but it turns out a whole bunch of recipes are published in newspapers every week, so most newspapers have like a weekly thing and we thought it might be interesting to see what that could tell us about.

Food trends now I don't have a definite answer yet of what food trends there are in newspapers in the Netherlands from 1945 to 1995 because this is really the creating the data set and now we're working with our humanities researchers, but we also invite everyone else to look at this and see what they can do with this data set, how they can you know what kind of analysis they could do.

So you know the main people in our buildings are historians, mythologist for example, but this could also be interesting for dietitians, for example, to see what people eat previously or what they thought was good food.
And you could say that newspapers are.
Sort of the everyday thing.
They would probably wouldn't publish things that people wouldn't cook, right?
It's not probably not the kind of stuff you get in a three star Michelin restaurants.
And actually, people have also been looking at restaurant menus, but that's a different type of research.
So we took full newspapers that were digitized by the Dutch National Library.
They actually.
We have 90 million.
Pages of newspapers, magazines, books, etc.
And, um, there's a theory that really Dutch food culture formed in the 1950s.
That was the period after the Second World War.
The NELONS was very heavily affected by that, and people had to sort of reinvent things.
'cause were shortages and all sorts of things.
Um?

So the problem with that is that if you just do a keyword search for recipes or accept it in Dutch, then you're also going to get back things that are how to create medicines or or medication prescriptions, because that is the same word in Dutch and obviously also not all newspapers they actually use.
The word recipe in their food categories because they say, well, what's for dinner tonight or they have a name like that?

And there's also noise from the digitization process, so we started with these because these were digitized fairly recently, but there's still noise because the newspapers are bound in these big books, so they open the page.
But there's actually like a shadow very often, or there's a fold in the page.
It was right in the middle of the book, so part of the text is actually illegible, and that poses some problems for the kind of things we wanted to do.
So this is our data set.
The main data set.
It's available for everyone, so this website that you see delford ottonel.
There are some some non Dutch language texts in there, but otherwise find a Dutch person to go through with you.
It's available to anyone, it's open and you can just search and you'll get things like like this, which this is the OCR scan.
You can download a JPEG text or PDF.
There's all sorts of information about this newspaper.
And this is just a website that everyone can use.
Then if you have a research agreement with them, you can also get access to the API or get data dumps.
Actually the older dumps are freely available because it's not copyrighted.
Um and they're still working on digitizing this now.
The full papers we used are about 48,000 pages.
It's not, it's only a small percentage, but it's it's still quite considerable in this.
Too much for humanities researcher to go through by hand.
Anne.
Then there was this other data set that we used, which was our domain specific datasets, which are recipes from a big supermarket chain in the Netherlands.
They have a website with 16,000 recipes.
We got in touch with them and we get to use these recipes and this is interesting for us because it tells us what does a recipe look like so we can train a machine learning algorithm on that.
They have schema.org markup so ingredients are sorted out in lists and marked up.
Plus they have tags, nutritional values, applications because they come out of a magazine and they've been publishing these recipe since 1974 think and a rating.
So how popular it is on the website, we don't do much with the rating at the moment, but it's it's an interesting thing to do.
Um?
For our pipeline, so here we've got the Alejandra recipe website, so this is our domain thing and we get what does a recipe look like to the descriptions we get, the tags, we get the ingredients.
Then we've got Delta.
We've got the newspapers, and the first thing we do is we have a seed list and we just try to find recipes with that.

So we have words like tablespoon and said I'll get into this steps in a bit and we use classification that results in Arctic newspaper articles that are most likely recipes and we actually get this with a pretty high accuracy score.
Then we take those articles and we are going to extract the ingredients and.
Quantities and we add the tags to it and I'll explain each step in a in subsequent slides.
So we've got structured recipes.
And then we're going to enrich them.
So link them to DB pedia and the global Biodiversity Information Facility, because that gives us information about where the ingredients come from.
So are we eating locally?
Or are we eating globally?
Right?
So to classify in tags, we first do the seed list and those results are in blue, so we don't get as many recipes from that as we would like.
So we use these two start to create a training data set and we also use the recipe description.

We have to sort of to train a machine learning algorithm to actually find more recipes in all these newspaper articles and those are the orange lines, so we find more and this is actually split out per newspaper.
Then what we did.
It was find the tags.
Now this top one is how often we have the tags.
How often we find those.
There are 69 possible tags reproing this a little because tags that only occur a couple of times in the training data set.
Probably not the most interesting thing to use an there's various things, so it's type of dish.
It's whether it's Italian or Indonesian.

The type of diet, whether it's a vegetarian gluten free, will probably not going to find that many gluten free things in the older newspapers, 'cause that's one of the problems with this, so there's a bit of a mismatch between the tags and.
Historic data set because.
Just it's already a remnant of changing food culture.
Lactose free was not a thing in 1945.
Um also occasion, so it says whether it's a group for Christmas dinner or maybe a Halloween recipe.
Cooking style where there is baking or boiling or cooking stuff like that grilling.
We evaluated manually evaluated three tags and this evaluation was kind of hard 'cause we going to evaluate all of them, but we chose to do three that were also sort of not too controversial.
And the schools are pretty good and Asian, Italian vegetarian.
Now.

The interesting thing is that some of the stuff that is tagged vegetarian is actually not vegetarian because it for example contains a even in the in the training data set they accidentally forgot that there was like shrimp in occur in a Curry paste or something.
So even in the training date, the gold standard data set their stuff to do.
Then there was a mentioned.
Um?
We also looked at the OCR quality, so for this we had a lexecon based OCR measurement, so a lot of OCR tools they come with.

A measure of how correct it is that's based on characters, and we're obviously interested in entire words, so we put together a lexicon, a dictionary that also contains older variants of Dutch, because actually our spelling changes quite a lot even in the past 50 years.
And we looked at the different newspaper, so the you know, here's a .6 correct?
And we looked at how many of the words in a dictionary can we actually find in the text.
So what you see here is the percentage of the sort of dictionary words that we can find.
You obviously want it to be pretty high, so it is pretty high, but there are still gaps in there and that really affects our natural language processing tools.
Because.
Um?
A lot of these natural language processing tools they expect correct sentences, grammatically correct sentences, and they also rely on recognizing words to the part of speech tagging.

But if you've got really, really weird words that are not really words speaking, but then just garbled up really weird characters because of the OCR, then it immediately breaks, and if it breaks at a very early stage in your NLP pipeline, then you've got a problem.
So for this we for now.
Use a lexicon based approach where we put together a lexecon of known ingredients, unknown quantities and use that.
But obviously this is something we want to improve and we're working with some colleagues who are experts in OCR correction.
Anne.
We did is we.
We manually annotated 100 articles using Rocoto, which is actually a tool for.
Marking geographical information, but it's a very very nice interface, so we misuse it a bit, but they're pretty cool about it.
And then we also so here in pink we marked OCR errors.
Still some measure the impact of that.
We only mark those ingredients and quantities that we found.
And the Inter Annotator agreement is pretty high, but this was the word bananas banana and it got really garbled up.
And then, especially when you've got these errors, then the annotators don't know where the word really begins and really ends.
So that's also partly where errors in or disagreements in the Inter annotator agreement come from.
So yeah, we're really looking for figuring out how to do these out of lexecon things, because obviously not all ingredients are in our lists.
Then about the linking.
So we basically took steps because we can link stuff directly, but it's a Dutch text, so we first linked it to the Dutch DB Pedia.
And that gives us the links to the English TV Pedia.
Plus it also gives us the scientific name now.
The Latin name.
That can be used to go to the global Biodiversity Information Facility.
To um to get, for example, where an ingredient comes from.
So tomatoes originate from South America.
Interestingly, the food covered in DB pedia is quite low, so we tried various things we try to purely string matching.
We also tried Spotlight, but because there's not very much food in DB pedia, you can already see that from the ontology.
The recall is pretty low on this and we're suffering.
We did look for other food resources in the linked open data Cloud, but they were very hard to find.
For example, the nutritional value.
So if anyone has any cool datasets that.
We just overlooked.
I'd be very happy to hear about that.
And that gives us some 27,000 knew old recipes from the past 50.
Well, not the past 50 years, but 50 years of data.
With a whole bunch of tags and links to other resources, the data set is available.
The original text from the newspapers are not available because of Copyright, but that identifies us.
You can always go to the Delta website and get them.
As well as the code, it would be very.

Testing to see if you could do this for English as well, because some of our historians are very interested in comparing whether Dutch food culture, how that compares to German and an English food culture.
For example an can we compare these recipes and see, for example, whether.
The food prices when they go up, for example for sugar, whether we start using less sugar in our recipes, or whether the recipes mention less sugar in those kind of things.
So that will be interesting to see.
Also, if we've got migration into our country and new people bring their new food cultures with them, at what point does it become integrated?
So we found newspaper articles that sort of mention an explanation of a new dish, and they go well explaining.
But by at some point that Dish becomes part of Dutch food culture.
Can we trace those things that would be super interesting.
Um?
Yeah, and then also we want to add ingredient prices.
There are databases for that, but the kind of hard to link.
So there's.
There's a big linking problem there.
Obviously we want to expand it also to the older newspapers.
Yes, so here you can actually see one of these problems with the digitalization, and this is really difficult for OCR software to deal with the lines that are not completely straight.
Um?
Yeah, so this is where all we have the data set we're now going to be working on analyzing it with our colleagues, but also if you have ideas that would be super cool and.
Um?
We'd like to thank the Dutch National Library, wrote museum, the Dutch Digital Heritage Network, and the Humanities cluster and the University of Amsterdam, where we are based.
Thank you very much.
